head.supplied: This magnificent and comparatively hardy plant is almost confined to Eastern Gippsland, passing — so far as known — only into the most southern part of New South Wales, it having been found by Mr. W. ...

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;
p.seg: Letter not found. The text given here is from 'Colonial notes. The Victorian Waratah (Telopea oreades)',
, 23 March 1889, p, 371 (B89.03.01). It is dated to early February as the latest likely date that it could have been sent to have appeared in this issue.

This magnificent and comparatively hardy plant is almost confined to Eastern Gippsland, passing — so far as known — only into the most southern part of New South Wales, it having been found by Mr. W. Baeuerlen at an elevation of about 3,500 feet at the southern sources of the Shoalhaven River.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;
p.seg: NSW. At about the same time as this letter was written, M sought the advice of members of the Linnean Society of NSW on the exact distribution of another
see M to J. Fletcher, February 1889 (in this edition as 89-02-00b).
During a recent tour of some members of the Victorian Field Naturalists' Club, undertaken at the suggestion of the writer,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: Mr. Charles French saw exceptionally fine trees, 60 feet high, with a considerable stem diameter. Mr. James Stirling also saw trees in the valley of the Ben River

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: fully 50 feet high. This superb species descends to valleys with Dicksonia Billardieri, Alsophila australis, and Senecio Bedfordi, as does Telopea truncata in Tasmania, from which species it is quite distinct in its always glabrous bracts, and some differences in the leaves and seeds. T. oreades was discovered in 1860

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: in the highlands at the sources of the Genoa, where some snow lies during the winter months, the elevation being about 4000 feet. What a splendid acquisition this plant would be in mild regions of England for outdoor culture.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in; font-style: italic;
